Yes, but it's not transfering to your new motherboard. You can transfer it to your new drive though. You can connect your new drive to your old PC, then use software like Macrium Reflect to clone your boot drive to the (intended) boot drive of your new PC.

However, when getting a new full system, it's recommended to do a fresh install of Windows. You can then connect your drive from your old PC and just copy over the files.

Well it‚Äôs a very long list but I will state the obvious ones:

- In order to prevent frying the electronics with built-up static electricity, people usually wear anti static bracelets and attach a metal clip to the bracelet and the other end goes into a metal part (usually the power supply) where the electricity can be safely transferred to. This stupid mofo just puts on a bracelet and nothing else is attached to the bracelet which is why people call it the ‚Äúlivestrong‚Äù bracelet.

- you don‚Äôt assemble a PC with a swiss army knife screwdriver. That‚Äôs very obvious and I it don‚Äôt think needs any explanation.

- processors usually come with a pre applied thermal paste to prevent overheating. Though the amount is controversial, usually, only a few drops of paste should be more than enough. Well, apparently it‚Äôs not for this person and he proceeds to empty the entire thing on the CPU which is a problem.

- with memory sticks, you should place them with an empty slot in between (either the 1st and 3rd slot or 2nd and the 4th slot) so you can get more performance out of them. Let alone the spacing, this stupid mofo put the ram stick the wrong way and broke it (which I think was replaced prior to booting by people who actually know PCs) 

That‚Äôs just a few examples and you can find much more online

Yes. You just go to disk management and format C:. At that point, you should be able to extend your E: volume to include the freshly formated C:. You'll only be able to do this after putting your install on your new SSD.
